definition: Quantum mechanical method that uses electron density rather than wavefunction as the fundamental variable to determine electronic structure and properties.
Mean-field approximation method that treats each electron as moving in the average field of all other electrons, expressed as a single Slater determinant.
The difference between the exact non-relativistic energy and the Hartree-Fock energy, arising from instantaneous electron-electron interactions beyond mean-field.
Quantum superconducting sensor material engineered for high sensitivity, advanced energy storage, and integration into critical infrastructure using elements like Ge, Ga, Nb, Ti, Al, and nitrides.

Technology Readiness Level - a systematic metric/measurement system that supports assessments of technology maturity from TRL 1 (basic principles) to TRL 9 (actual system proven in operational environment).
AI-driven systematic method to determine relationships between factors affecting a process and the output of that process, used in Q-SMEC for materials optimization.
Proprietary sensor and energy storage platform using quantum-optimized superconducting materials in multi-layer configurations for ultra-sensitive detection and energy containment.
Q-SMEC proprietary metric for superconducting material optimization combining atomic packing density with quantum coherence and energy containment efficiency.
Minimum incident optical power required to produce signal-to-noise ratio of unity in 1 Hz bandwidth. Q-SMEC achieves 0.01-1 pW/Hz.
Ratio of signal power to noise power, typically expressed in decibels. Q-SMEC sensors achieve >120 dB SNR.
Composite performance metric for sensors. For THz: FOM = (Responsivity  Bandwidth) / NEP. Q-SMEC achieves >2500.
NASA/DOD 9-level scale measuring technology maturity from basic research (TRL 1) to operational deployment (TRL 9).
Key design constraints for aerospace, defense, and mobile applications requiring optimization of physical dimensions, mass, power consumption, and economics.
DOD framework with 3 levels for assessing and certifying cybersecurity posture of defense contractors handling CUI.

full_name: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program
definition: Government-wide program providing standardized security assessment for cloud services at Low, Moderate, or High impact levels.
US regulations controlling export and access to defense articles, technical data, and services listed on the USML.
Metal-organic framework battery materials with open structure enabling fast ion transport and long cycle life (>10,000 cycles).
Measure of how detectable an object is by radar, proportional to scattered power. Q-SMEC metamaterials reduce RCS for stealth.
Industrial control system for monitoring and controlling infrastructure, manufacturing, and utilities. Q-SMEC integrates AI-SCADA for predictive maintenance.
Device measuring acceleration and angular velocity using accelerometers and gyroscopes. Q-SMEC quantum IMUs enable GPS-denied navigation.
Satellite-based positioning system (GPS, GLONASS, Galileo, BeiDou). Q-SMEC provides GPS-denied navigation alternatives.
Electromagnetic radiation with frequency 0.1-10 THz (wavelength 3 mm - 30 μm), between microwave and infrared. Non-ionizing, penetrates many materials.
Ultra-sensitive magnetometer using Josephson junctions. Achieves <1 fT/Hz sensitivity for biomagnetic, geophysical, and defense applications.
Brain imaging technique measuring magnetic fields produced by neuronal activity. Requires <1 fT sensitivity. Q-SMEC enables room-temperature MEG.
Cardiac imaging technique measuring magnetic fields from heart electrical activity. Non-contact alternative to ECG.
Inspection techniques that do not damage the inspected object. Q-SMEC THz sensors enable composite inspection, corrosion detection, and defect identification.
Electromagnetic radiation 3-30 Hz. Penetrates seawater for submarine communications. Q-SMEC enables compact ELF antennas.
Electromagnetic radiation 3-30 kHz. Used for navigation, time signals, and long-range communication.
Hardware fingerprint exploiting manufacturing variations for device authentication and secure key generation. Q-SMEC uses quantum material PUFs.
Unclassified information requiring safeguarding under federal law, regulation, or policy. CMMC addresses CUI protection.
Military action involving electromagnetic spectrum including electronic attack (EA), electronic protection (EP), and electronic support (ES).
Military activities coordinating intelligence collection, surveillance operations, and reconnaissance for situational awareness.
Weapons emitting concentrated electromagnetic energy (lasers, HPM) or particle beams. Q-SMEC enables high-power solid-state lasers.
Directed energy weapon emitting high-power microwave pulses to disable electronics. Related to Q-SMEC EM sensing.
Knowledge of space objects, environment, and threats. Q-SMEC sensors enable improved tracking and characterization.
Device providing attitude (roll, pitch, yaw) information using IMU, magnetometer, and sometimes GPS.
Automotive safety systems including ACC, LKA, AEB. Q-SMEC Lidar enables enhanced ADAS performance.
Remote sensing using laser pulses to measure distances and create 3D maps. Q-SMEC enhances Lidar sensitivity and range.
Dimensionless parameter quantifying thermoelectric material performance: ZT = SσT/(κe+κL). Higher ZT = better efficiency.
Quantum mechanical method using electron density to calculate material properties. Q-SMEC uses DFT for material screening.
Numerical method solving Maxwell equations on discrete grid. Used for metamaterial and antenna design.
One-time costs for design, development, and tooling. Q-SMEC instantiation NRE:  over 6 tasks.
Total market demand for a product or service. Q-SMEC use cases span .2B- TAMs across sectors.
Year-over-year growth rate assuming constant compounding. Q-SMEC markets show 6-42% CAGRs.
Present value of future cash flows minus initial investment. Used to value Q-SMEC licensing opportunities.
US federal agency responsible for public security. Q-SMEC targets 16 DHS Critical Infrastructure Sectors.
US federal agency overseeing energy policy and national labs. Q-SMEC aligns with DOE energy storage and quantum initiatives.
DOD research agency developing breakthrough technologies for national security. Q-SMEC targets DARPA quantum sensing programs.
